awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Pan American Nanotechnology Conference 2: Growing Convergence in Nanotechnology: Brazil - March 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past 20 years, there has been a high level of activity and innovation in nanotechnology with growing understanding at how molecular scale phenomena manifests at the nano scale and eventually the system scale. Additionally, critical societal needs in the areas of energy, water, bioprocessing, and the environment are providing exciting new opportunities for nanotechnology. This project provides support for travel and registration expenses for graduate student, postdoctoral research fellow and faculty attendees of the second Pan American Nanotechnology Conference. The conference will be held from March 4th through 7th of 2020 at the Majestic Hotel, in Aguas de Lindoia, Sao Paulo, Brazil. The conference focus is on nanotechnology broadly and the attendant applications for a wide range of industrial and environmental processes of critical importance to U.S. technology competitiveness. The conference will also provide valuable educational, career development, and networking opportunities for students and early-career researchers. The conference theme of Growing Convergence in Nanotechnology will provide a venue for research convergence in different fields of nanomaterials and nanotechnology, such as social, legal, medical, agricultural, material design and synthesis, and modeling. This will enhance collaborative and impactful research at the nanoscale throughout the Pan American region. The conference will also foster informal discussions and networking that will occur outside of the formal lecture sessions among its participants from North, South and Central America. Such interactions aim to promote the generation of new ideas and new collaborations that assist in moving forward the field of nanotechnology. The organizers have also made special efforts to include women and underrepresented minorities in the conference. 

The Pan American Nanotechnology Conference will have specific sessions on the applications and impacts of nanotechnology on water quality and treatment, agricultural systems, devices such as sensors, medicine, nanomanufacturing and process intensification. The conference will be held from March 4th through 7th of 2020 at the Majestic Hotel, in Aguas de Lindoia, Sao Paulo, Brazil. The discussions between the speakers and audience will provide valuable feedback on current research efforts and will enable the participants to further develop and refine new ideas for their own research and/or to initiate new collaborative nanotechnology projects. The Pan American Nanotechnology Conference aims to provide a setting where researchers can present their most recent results. The conference will also foster informal discussions and networking that will occur outside of the formal lecture sessions among its participants from North, South and Central America. Such interactions aim to promote the generation of new ideas and new collaborations that assist in moving forward the field of nanotechnology. The organizers have also made special efforts to include women and underrepresented minorities in the conference. Notably the conference will include a modified and expanded Gordon Research Conferences "Power Hour" informal gathering for all meeting participants to discuss the challenges that women, ethnic and gender minorities, persons with disabilities and people with non-traditional background/experience face in science. This event helps to create an awareness of these important issues among the broader community such that the whole community can act to support the professional growth of women and underrepresented groups in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcome Report: Second Pan American Nanotechnology ConferenceDate: March 4th-7th, [Year] Location: Aguas de Lindoia, Sao Paulo, BrazilIntroduction: This outcome report aims to provide an overview of the second Pan American Nanotechnology Conference held in Aguas de Lindoia, Sao Paulo, Brazil. The conference, which took place from March 4th to 7th, [Year], brought together researchers, postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students from the United States and various countries in Latin America, Europe, and Asia. The primary objective of the conference was to foster collaboration, knowledge exchange, and research convergence in the field of nanotechnology across the Pan American region.Participation: The conference witnessed enthusiastic participation, with a total of 257 attendees. Among them, 132 were female and 125 were male. Out of the participants, 70 represented the United States, and 53 of them received partial funding support for their attendance. The remaining participants comprised individuals from different Latin American countries, Europe, and Asia. The conference aimed to promote diversity and inclusivity by providing travel support to underrepresented groups, including racial minorities, females, researchers/students with disabilities, and early career scientists.Conference Theme: The theme of the second Pan American Nanotechnology Conference was "Growing Convergence in Nanotechnology." The theme reflected the objective of fostering research collaboration and convergence in various fields of nanomaterials and nanotechnology. The conference aimed to explore diverse areas such as social implications, legal aspects, medical applications, agricultural advancements, synthesis techniques, modeling, and impactful nanoscale research throughout the Pan American region.Activities: The conference featured a range of engaging activities that facilitated networking, knowledge sharing, and scientific discourse. These activities included:1. Networking Luncheons and Dinners: Participants had the opportunity to connect and interact during networking luncheons and dinners, fostering collaborations and meaningful discussions.2. Opening Ceremony: The conference commenced with an inspiring plenary session delivered by Professor Pedro Alvarez, the George R. Brown Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Rice University. Professor Alvarez, the founding Director of the NSF Engineering Research Center on Nanotechnology-Enabled Water Treatment (NEWT), set the tone for the conference with his insightful address.3. Plenary Sessions: The conference featured eight plenary sessions, addressing key topics and emerging trends in nanotechnology research. These sessions provided a platform for renowned experts to share their expertise and insights.4. Oral and Poster Presentations: Attendees had the opportunity to present their research findings through oral and poster presentations. These sessions showcased cutting-edge research and stimulated discussions among participants.5. TED-Style Poster Presentations: A highlight of the conference was the inclusion of 72 TED-style short poster presentations specifically for students and postdoctoral fellows participating in the Poster Competition. This format allowed participants to succinctly present their work and engage the audience effectively.Outcomes and Impact: The second Pan American Nanotechnology Conference successfully achieved its objectives, resulting in several outcomes and impactful contributions. These include:1. Collaboration and Networking: The conference served as a catalyst for collaboration and networking among researchers, facilitating connections between scientists from the United States and various countries in Latin America. The event fostered an environment for knowledge exchange, paving the way for future collaborations and partnerships.2. Research Convergence: The conference's theme of "Growing Convergence in Nanotechnology" promoted interdisciplinary collaborations and research convergence in diverse fields. The discussions and presentations explored the convergence of nanotechnology with social, legal, medical, agricultural, synthesis, modeling, and application domains, contributing to impactful research in the Pan American region.3.
